name: TheAtlantic
text: What did we lose when the White House mandated hospitals stop sending data to the CDC? @AlexisMadrigal explains: https://t.co/jCcbTv4JFB

name: TheAtlantic
text: "These dismal times, as the virus rages and historic protests continue in the wake of George Floyd’s slaying, can be the springboard for a Third Reconstruction," @wuc3 writes: https://t.co/2MnukW2gTM

name: TheAtlantic
text:
A South Korean study has found that older children can spread the coronavirus just as much as adults.

Earlier this month, @SarahCohodes argued that schools must prioritize reopening for younger children. https://t.co/3UxvvZnqn7

name: TheAtlantic
text: “The unmitigated injury of slavery and racism did not end with abolition or the civil-rights era; instead, like interest on debt, its impact has compounded," @wuc3 writes. "Continued inaction...will make racial justice ever more difficult to achieve."https://t.co/FpYoGim4uo

name: TheAtlantic
text: Just in: The man suspected of shooting Judge Esther Salas’s husband and son in their New Jersey home had published 10,000 pages of racism, misogyny, and support for President Trump online. He also attacked Salas by name, @jbenton reports: https://t.co/EEklY1MxF2

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @AdrienneLaF: There's way more detail in the documents @jbenton uncovered compared with what's already been reported. This story just went live, and it's disturbing:  https://t.co/4GmecsJHDr

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @prashantrao: Italy rallied after being hit hard by the pandemic. But it is not out of the woods. The coronavirus exposed the West's weakest link, @RachelDonadio writes: https://t.co/Bo0ZGJTKOT

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @YAppelbaum: President Trump is cobbling together something the U.S. has never had before—a national police force, used to quell protests. https://t.co/2zqO7cAjSe

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @beccarosen: .@jbenton read through the online writings of Roy Den Hollander, the suspected shooter of the NJ judge's family. “The Feminists should be careful…," Den Hollander wrote. "There are 300 million firearms in this country, and most of them are owned by guys.” https://t.co/IEj13ZMKpb

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @JeffreyGoldberg: "Tulane and other campuses are slated to reopen for in-person instruction in the fall. Students will get infected, and universities will rebuke them for it; campuses will close, and students will be blamed for it."
https://t.co/8UteGhr51I

name: TheAtlantic
text: "The past decade has witnessed a dangerous trend: a Supreme Court that expresses deep suspicion of Congress’s competence and motives," Jonathan S. Gould and Olatunde C. A. Johnson write: https://t.co/VkfbeMzcI6

name: TheAtlantic
text: Italy rallied after being hit hard by the pandemic. But it is not out of the woods. The coronavirus exposed the West's weakest link, @RachelDonadio writes: https://t.co/3kmAFIb23m

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @DKThomp: In 1995, the NRA fundraised by condemning Clinton's “jackbooted thugs" that would "harass, intimidate, even murder law-abiding citizens."

On Thursday, the NRA endorsed Trump, as his armored officers harassed and detained peaceful protesters in Portland.

https://t.co/yjpwzynHxt https://t.co/Dcay8sd1pt

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @GrahamDavidA: 25 years ago, the NRA warned of "jackbooted thugs" from the federal government taking away citizens' rights.

Last week they appeared, in Portland, at Donald Trump's command—just as the NRA endorsed Trump for reelection: https://t.co/KCGOk5SS8U

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @LaurieAbraham2: The events chronicled here have to be read to believed. And the video is as powerful and haunting as the storytelling. Major props to The Marshall Project's Eli Hager for this powerful story about restorative justice. https://t.co/7LrN6K6aUa

name: TheAtlantic
text: "It should be quite unthinkable for armed officers exercising coercive arrest powers in the streets of an American city to not identify themselves by name and affiliation," @qjurecic and @benjaminwittes write:https://t.co/DEqxM2LSv1

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Trump appears to be trying to do something novel in this country: establishing a force like interior ministries in other countries," writes @GrahamDavidA: https://t.co/AnSKTufogE

name: TheAtlantic
text: The man suspected of shooting Judge Esther Salas’s husband and son in their New Jersey home had published 10,000 pages of racism, misogyny, and support for President Trump online. He also attacked Salas by name, @jbenton reports: https://t.co/mnsBG0l36P

name: TheAtlantic
text: "College campuses that are reopening for in-person instruction are banking on the personal responsibility of students to make it all work—and students are being set up to take the fall when the plans fail," @JuliaLMarcus and @drjessigold write. https://t.co/rqzU9DIufV

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @thebanderson: The science behind Randonautica—that people can use “micro-psychokinesis” to affect machines in very small ways—is tenuous, at best. 

But hey, randomness can be its own reward, as @kait_tiffany found out: https://t.co/P3EHYmHg3b

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @JamesFallows: Three proposals for what comes next—politically, economically, in education and inclusion—if we survive the current nightmares:

Guide and summary by me:  https://t.co/5SdJlqi7Q0

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @elainejgodfrey: "Maybe there’s a kind of restorative justice that is impossible because both parties are broken..." 

What a read, from @elibhager 

https://t.co/2c6GTQ5Rge

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @julieebeck: can work friendships survive remote work?

https://t.co/Roi4XUibLN

name: TheAtlantic
text: Kicking the Our Towns series off again, @JamesFallows rounds up three recent guides for America's resilience and recovery: https://t.co/Yo3ZTQOXMd

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @elibhager: In early 2019, while reporting another story, I found something fascinating in Jacksonville, the murder capital of Florida and a death penalty bastion. The prosecutor there, Melissa Nelson, was trying restorative justice in murder cases, which is unheard of (thread) 1/In early 2019, while reporting another story, I found something fascinating in Jacksonville, the murder capital of… https://t.co/oiveYOOmVp

name: TheAtlantic
text: For the family of one murder victim, restorative justice was a balm that led to forgiveness. For another, it went almost unbelievably wrong. @elibhager reports on the meaning of restorative justice: https://t.co/Q40VhLdMDv

name: TheAtlantic
text: Work friendships are born of convenience and necessity—and the pandemic is showing which can survive without 40-hour-a-week proximity, Nicole Mo writes. If widespread remote work sticks around, these relationships will never be the same: https://t.co/GsXfXGsMYf

name: TheAtlantic
text: The science behind Randonautica is shaky at best, but some of the adventures are real, @kait_tiffany reports. How a random-coordinates generator became the app of the summer: https://t.co/iTiQ74iWvV

name: TheAtlantic
text: When it comes to the daunting question of reopening schools, America’s educators deserve a plan, not a trap. Dave Grohl writes about the country’s responsibility to people like his mother, a former public-school teacher: https://t.co/f9oXbLXBvQ

name: TheAtlantic
text: Voice acting has long been under scrutiny about race and representation. But the recent wave of white actors departing from roles that depict characters of color has delivered a shock to the industry, shirklesxp reports. https://t.co/okuxZAUexd

name: TheAtlantic
text: On an episode of the podcast Social Distance, @jameshamblin talks about what he learned about the concept of cleanliness in writing his new book. https://t.co/Qo1P9GCxek

name: TheAtlantic
text: “Though no one would ever wish it to happen this way,” @JamesHamblin writes, “the pandemic could mark a chance to reexamine how much cleanliness is good for us, and what practices we’d be better off without.” https://t.co/ue1RY9gSM2

name: TheAtlantic
text: Photos: Paws in the Water—Dogs at Play, via @TheAtlPhoto: https://t.co/e1odBpORzH

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @nora_kelly: Rep. Debbie Dingell of Michigan warned the Clinton campaign four years ago that their candidate was bleeding white, working-class voters. Now, she tells @elainejgodfrey: "I’m seeing lots of Trump signs start to pop up." https://t.co/v9xtwMUp28

name: TheAtlantic
text: Voice acting has long been under scrutiny about race and representation. But the recent wave of white actors departing from roles that depict characters of color has delivered a shock to the industry, @shirklesxp reports. https://t.co/TuE2bE12Gs

name: TheAtlantic
text: "For some current and former Republicans—skeptical of socialism but disgusted by Trump’s pitiless narcissism—a message of bipartisan, ideologically flexible compassion has deep appeal," @PeterBeinart writes: https://t.co/WS5Jc9f5pR

name: TheAtlantic
text:
"Raising awareness about racism is not a means in itself of correcting injustice."

@saigrundy on the deceptive passivity of the anti-racist reading list: https://t.co/Wj8JGGNx54

name: TheAtlantic
text: President Trump is restarting his daily televised coronavirus briefings today. In April, Peter Nicholas predicted that as the election approaches, Trump may be more and more tempted to use the presidential spotlight for his own purposes: https://t.co/r5AdkliPhH

name: TheAtlantic
text: Michigan Representative Debbie Dingell was one of the few Democrats who saw Donald Trump coming. She’s worried her party will underestimate him again, she tells @elainejgodfrey: https://t.co/LpgmdyDPYk

name: TheAtlantic
text:
1/ States are reopening, but the pandemic continues. 

Choices that were once simple now require calculated thought… https://t.co/5irzXwJSg2

name: TheAtlantic
text:
2/ If you have to return to the office or stay in a hotel while traveling, should you worry about air conditioning transmitting the virus? 

“There’s currently no clear evidence … But the presumption is that it could.” https://t.co/6hbLDHGhin

name: TheAtlantic
text:
3/ Some local authorities are allowing large weddings again. Is it okay to attend?

“Just because local officials haven’t forbidden something doesn’t make it safe. Legal can’t be mistaken for wise,” Hamblin says. https://t.co/wZSehjSBHG

name: TheAtlantic
text:
4/ Is it safe to fly right now?

Outbreaks of the coronavirus on airplanes are unlikely as long as everyone keeps a few things in mind, Hamblin reports. https://t.co/UPHAKGdqtP

name: TheAtlantic
text:
5/ What about singing? 

“In the context of so much being shut down, the question … may sound trivial. But it’s not at all,” Hamblin writes.

“Thousands of lives may hang on how it is done.” https://t.co/QI9iGPsqLG

name: TheAtlantic
text:
6/ As parents consider virtual versus in-person learning this fall, they shouldn’t discount the effects of the virus on children.

Hamblin explains why it’s a safe assumption that COVID-19 “is affecting more children than we currently realize”: https://t.co/bSR7Bd2iJR

name: TheAtlantic
text:
7/ Elderberry. Vitamin tonics. The internet is full of ads for dietary supplements that imply they’ll protect us from COVID-19. 

One standout that’s steadily gained actual scientific traction: vitamin D. https://t.co/fcWcgziuBC

name: TheAtlantic
text: 8/ Have a question for James Hamblin about navigating life during the pandemic? Email paging.dr.hamblin@theatlantic… https://t.co/EbHC1rtzhE

name: TheAtlantic
text: "There is something repugnant about Trump, yes, but there is also something quite sad about the man. He is a damaged soul," @Peter_Wehner writes: https://t.co/OXcBK0VfoQ
